channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Economy in double-dip recession
item.description: The UK returns to recession, after a sharp fall in construction leads to the economy shrinking by 0.2% in the first three months of 2012.

item.title: Hunt defends BSkyB takeover role
item.description: Culture Secretary Jeremy Hunt tells MPs he "followed due process" in the BSkyB takeover bid - but his special adviser quits over his contacts with News Corp.

item.title: Brown 'pledged war with Murdoch'
item.description: Rupert Murdoch tells the Leveson Inquiry former Prime Minister Gordon Brown was not in "a balanced state of mind" when he declared "war" on News Corporation.

item.title: Iran 'undecided on nuclear bomb'
item.description: The head of the Israeli military says he does not think Iran will develop nuclear weapons, partly because international pressure is bearing fruit.

item.title: Heavy rain brings flood warnings
item.description: Flood warnings are in force in south-west England, which is in drought, while northern and eastern Scotland have been placed on flood alert.

item.title: Spy's death and work 'not linked'
item.description: Police tell the inquest for MI6 officer Gareth Williams that there was no link between his work for the intelligence service and his death.

item.title: Employers 'can force retirement'
item.description: A landmark ruling by the UK Supreme Court outlines the powers that employers have to force workers to retire.

item.title: Newt Gingrich 'to quit campaign'
item.description: Republican presidential hopeful Newt Gingrich will suspend his long-shot campaign next week, US media report, citing his aides.

item.title: Breivik: Insanity report is lies
item.description: Anders Behring Breivik tells his Oslo trial that a psychiatric report finding him insane in relation to his 77 killings last July is a fabrication.

item.title: 'Madeleine at nine' image created
item.description: British police reviewing the evidence around Madeleine McCann's disappearance in Portugal five years ago issue an image of what she might look like now.

item.title: HSBC 'to cut 2,000 staff in UK'
item.description: Banking giant HSBC is set to announce 2,000 job losses in the UK on Thursday as part of its global cost-cutting plans, reports say.

item.title: Teacher numbers fall by 10,000
item.description: The number of teachers in England's state schools system fell by 10,000 in the year to November, government figures show.

item.title: Bussell hired as Strictly judge
item.description: Ballet star Darcey Bussell is confirmed as the new judge on BBC One's Strictly Come Dancing.

item.title: Cutty Sark reopened by the Queen
item.description: The Cutty Sark is reopened by the Queen in Greenwich to mark the completion of a £50m restoration.

item.title: Demand for airliners helps Boeing
item.description: Airlines updating their fleets with more fuel-efficient planes boost Boeing, which reports 58% growth in three-month profits.

item.title: Eurozone leaders push for growth
item.description: Eurozone leaders urge governments to prioritise growth as the debt-addled regions struggles with grinding austerity.

item.title: Ban packed lunches, says Price ex
item.description: Reality TV star and former cage fighter Alex Reid calls for a ban on school packed lunches in a speech in Parliament.

item.title: NHS 'wastes billions on diabetes'
item.description: The bulk of the £9.8bn the NHS spends on diabetes each year is wasted - and the disease could cost it a sixth of its entire budget by 2035, says a report.

item.title: Aspirin 'can cut cancer deaths'
item.description: Bowel cancer patients who take aspirin daily could cut their chance of dying from the disease by about a third, experts believe.

item.title: Shakespeare's 'co-author' named
item.description: All's Well That Ends Well had a second writer, most likely Thomas Middleton, suggests research from Oxford University.

item.title: Junk food 'still placed at tills'
item.description: Supermarkets stand accused of undermining parents' attempts to feed their families healthily by continuing to place junk food near checkouts.

item.title: Insecure websites set to be named
item.description: Companies that do not do enough to keep their websites secure are to be named and shamed to help improve security.

item.title: Apple rejects laptop-tablet mix
item.description: Apple chief executive Tim Cook rejects the idea of combining laptops and tablets, a vision being pursued by Intel and others.

item.title: German satellite on 'berg watch'
item.description: The German radar satellite TerraSAR-X is returning regular images of the Pine Island Glacier ice shelf, to try to catch the birth of a giant berg.

item.title: Limbless amphibian species found
item.description: A UK-Indian team of scientists have announced the discovery of a new species of limbless amphibian.

item.title: Jackson presents Hobbit footage
item.description: Director Peter Jackson unveils 10 minutes of footage of The Hobbit to a mixed reaction at the CinemaCon convention in the US.

item.title: Jack White to write Ranger music
item.description: Jack White will write, produce and perform the music for the Lone Ranger movie, the film's producer confirms.

item.title: The terrible price of a Korean defection
item.description: South Korean economist Oh Kil-nam regrets having defected to North Korea

item.title: Why do so many French people vote?
item.description: The turnout in the French presidential election was more than 80%. Why are the French so politically engaged?

item.title: Di Matteo 'deserves to stay on'
item.description: Roberto di Matteo should stay in charge of Champions League finalists Chelsea for at least another year, says Avram Grant.

item.title: Clubs vote for financial changes
item.description: Championship clubs making losses of more than £6m will be fined or put under a transfer embargo from 2014-15.

item.title: British athlete fails doping test
item.description: British Bobsleigh confirms that one of its athletes has been provisionally suspended after testing positive for a banned substance.

item.title: Marathon donations cross £600,000
item.description: More than £600,000 is donated to a charity championed by a 30-year-old woman who died on the last leg of the London Marathon.

item.title: 'Shock' over rounders girl death
item.description: Tributes are paid to a 15-year-old Kent schoolgirl who collapsed and died during a game of rounders.

item.title: Trump 'lured' into opening resort
item.description: Tycoon Donald Trump has said he was "lured" into building a £1bn golf resort in Scotland with assurances that a nearby wind farm would not go ahead.

item.title: MHL to hand over Rangers papers
item.description: Sir David Murray's company is ordered to hand over copies of correspondence with Craig Whyte's lawyers over the sale of Rangers.

item.title: Mother gives grandparent evidence
item.description: The mother of a severely disabled girl gives evidence in the trial of the child's grandparents who are accused of her manslaughter.

item.title: Ilex head faces MLAs' questions
item.description: The head of Londonderry's regeneration body is due to appear before a Stormont committee to face questions over how it spent more than £400,000 without proper government approval.

item.title: Hotel behaviour inquiry into AM
item.description: An AM is referred to the Welsh assembly's standards watchdog after claims about his behaviour in a luxury hotel after a night out.

item.title: Cardiff Olympics rings unveiled
item.description: The Olympic rings are officially unveiled in Cardiff to mark Wales's involvement with London 2012's sporting and cultural events this summer.

item.title: Libya bans faith-based parties
item.description: Libyan authorities ban the formation of political parties based on religious principles, tribe or ethnicity ahead of elections scheduled for June.

item.title: Key Mali posts go to the military
item.description: The interim president of Mali announces a new government, appointing three military personnel to key posts.

item.title: Bo Xilai's son defends lifestyle
item.description: The son of disgraced Chinese politician Bo Xilai defends his lifestyle in a letter to his university and expresses "deep concern" about his family.

item.title: Philippine rebels kill soldiers
item.description: Ten Philippine solders have been killed in an ambush by communist rebels in the north of the country, officials say.

item.title: German athlete exposes 'stalker'
item.description: Star German high-jumper Ariane Friedrich names an alleged stalker on Facebook, citing self-defence, and the move sparks a new debate about privacy.

item.title: Sarkozy rules out far right deal
item.description: French President Nicolas Sarkozy rules out doing any election deal with the far-right National Front but says its voters should not be demonised.

item.title: Top US court to weigh migrant law
item.description: The US Supreme Court is considering yet another highly politically charged case - this time over Arizona's controversial immigration law.

item.title: Brazil delays key forest law vote
item.description: Brazil's Congress delays a final vote on controversial changes to the country's forest code which enviromentalists say will spur Amazon deforestation.

item.title: Troops 'bombard Damascus suburbs'
item.description: Syrian security forces have fired mortar shells and machine-guns at two suburbs of Damascus recently visited by UN monitors, activists say.

item.title: Police injured by Bahrain blast
item.description: A bomb explosion has wounded four members of Bahrain's police force - two of them seriously - during clashes with protesters, officials say.

item.title: S Korea firms halt US beef sales
item.description: Two of South Korea's biggest retailers halt sales of US beef after the discovery of a case of "mad cow" disease in California.

item.title: Obama slams 'knucklehead' agents
item.description: President Obama describes US Secret Service agents caught up in the Colombia sex scandal as "knuckleheads", saying that most do an "incredible" job.

item.title: Day in pictures: 24 April 2012
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 24 April

item.title: Cutty Sark ship-shape once again
item.description: Cutty Sark reopens after five-year restoration

item.title: In pictures: The Ford Transit
item.description: Celebration of the Ford Transit, from 1965 to now

item.title: In pictures: Giants leave Liverpool
item.description: Giant marionettes have left Liverpool by boat

item.title: Day in pictures: 23 April 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 23 April 2012

item.title: In pictures: The London Marathon
item.description: Runners in the 32nd London Marathon

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 April 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 April 2012

item.title: Your pictures: Fields
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of fields

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are debating the Civil Aviation Bill at report stage.

item.title: VIDEO: Why rain won't help English drought
item.description: The Environment Agency has issued seven flood warnings in south-west England, a region currently in drought.

item.title: VIDEO: Skydiver: 'Fear keeps you awake'
item.description: Adventurer Felix Baumgartner is planning to skydive from an altitude of 120,000 feet (36.7 km) this summer.

item.title: VIDEO: The pitfalls of all-inclusive holidays
item.description: All-inclusive holidays have soared in popularity in recent years, yet not everyone is happy with the growth of these deals.

item.title: VIDEO: Harman attacks Hunt over BSkyB
item.description: Labour's Harriet Harman says Jeremy Hunt has "fallen very far short" of the standards required of him regarding his role in News Corp's bid to take over BSkyB.

item.title: VIDEO: Mining asteroids for gold and platinum
item.description: Details have been emerging of the plan by billionaire entrepreneurs to mine asteroids for their resources.

item.title: VIDEO: Activists target child marriages
item.description: Campaigners in Bangladesh are stepping up their efforts to put a stop to child marriages.

item.title: VIDEO: 'A month's worth of rain' expected
item.description: As much as a month's worth of rain could fall in Wales and the south of England over the next few days, but water companies say it will not be enough to replenish reservoirs.

item.title: VIDEO: Targeted for talking to UN monitors?
item.description: The UN special envoy, Kofi Annan, has told the Security Council that Syria is still witnessing unacceptable levels of violence, despite a ceasefire being in place since 12 April.

item.title: Could teenagers be stopped from looking at porn?
item.description: Can you stop teenagers looking at online porn?

item.title: What's the best way to store rainwater?
item.description: What's the best way to scoop up all this rainwater?

item.title: Twitter hashtag's political power
item.description: How Twitter's hashtag is helping shape the political debate

item.title: In pictures: Charles Taylor's rebellions
item.description: A look back at ex-Liberian President Charles Taylor's role in conflicts

item.title: Can we count animal extinctions?
item.description: Can we count how many species are becoming extinct?

item.title: In pictures: The return of the fairground sideshow
item.description: The return of the fairground sideshow
